graph.original_query: What was the AQI in bangalore yesterday

text.content: Bengaluru air turns dirtier month by month, 2025 worst in five years WELCOME, My Times LOGOUT SIGN IN Tue ,Dec 30, 2025 Mumbai Mirror | Pune Mirror Home Bangalore Cover Story Crime Civic Other Elections Entertainment Bollywood Hollywood Reviews Lounge South Masala Videos sectionhomelist News Sports Entertainment Photos Entertainment News Sports Sports Cricket Football Tennis Others News State India World Business Opinion Ask the Sexpert Sunday Read You Code 560 Others Views Food Teen Spirit Blogs Loksabha Elections Photos Videos Schedule Campaign Tracker Modi Meter Coronavirus All Coronavirus Cover Story Crime Civic Other Elections News Photos Videos Bangalore Cover story Crime Civic Others Entertainment Bollywood Hollywood Reviews Lounge South Masala Videos News Sports Entertainment Photos Entertainment News Sports Sports Cricket Football Tennis Others News State India World Business Opinion Ask the Sexpert Sunday Read You Code 560 Others Views Food Teen Spirit Blogs Others Letters to the Editor Sci-Tech Leisure Trending Today Lit.Mus 2014 Home / Bangalore / Civic / Bengaluru air turns dirtier month by month, 2025 worst in five years Bengaluru air turns dirtier month by month, 2025 worst in five years Updated: Dec 29, 2025, 06:00 IST Facebook Twitter Linkedin Email Share Facebook Twitter Linkedin Email Print this article Reduce font size Increase font size Bengalurus air quality has shown a steady month-on-month decline in 2025, overtaking pollution levels recorded five years ago and marking the citys worst performance in recent times. Data from monitoring centres shows that the average Air Quality Index has crossed 2020 levels, with overall air quality dropping by 22 per cent compared to last year. Grim comparison In February 2020, Bengalurus average AQI stood at 131. By December 27 this year, the average had climbed to 143, indicating a clear deterioration. On December 21, the city recorded an AQI of 175, placing it firmly in the unhealthy category. Experts point out that breathing Bengalurus air for a day is now equivalent to smoking nearly three cigarettes, underlining the health risk posed by prolonged exposure. Compared to previous years, 2025 has emerged as the most polluted year in the last five-year period. Seasonal spike Pollution levels began rising sharply after October this year. From December 5 onwards, the daily average AQI has consistently remained above 149. The city recorded a one-day average AQI of 166 on December 15, the second-highest daily average of the year. A similar spike was seen on November 28, when the AQI touched 167. Between October 1 and December 15, November 22 was the only day when the AQI dipped to a relatively low 52, falling under the good category, according to the data. Monthly pattern Month-wise data for 2025 shows worrying fluctuations. Out of 361 days in 2025 till December 27, Bengaluru enjoyed good air quality in only two days. Air quality was satisfactory on 253 days, moderate on 81 days and unhealthy on 24 days. Relief came briefly during the monsoon months, with July at 60, August at 57 and September at 63. However, pollution levels climbed again post-monsoon, with October at 83, November at 124 and December averaging 143 so far. Out of 361 days in 2025 till December 27, Bengaluru enjoyed good air quality in only two days. Air quality was satisfactory on 253 days, moderate on 81 days and unhealthy on 24 days. Monitoring data confirms that no other year in the last five years has recorded such consistently high pollution levels. For comparison, the citys average AQI stood at 86 in 2020, 84 in 2021, 87 in 2022, 78 in 2023 and 73 in 2024, before jumping sharply in 2025. GALLERIES View more photos Aero India 2021: 13th edition of air show begins today Pedestrians Only! Newly upgraded footpath on Kanakapura Road in ruins PRR: Landowners offered record com

Active children and adults, and people with respiratory disease, such as asthma, should limit prolonged outdoor exertion. 101-150 Unhealthy for Sensitive Groups Members of sensitive groups may experience health effects. The general public is not likely to be affected. Active children and adults, and people with respiratory disease, such as asthma, should limit prolonged outdoor exertion. 151-200 Unhealthy Everyone may begin to experience health effects; members of sensitive groups may experience more serious health effects Active children and adults, and people with respiratory disease, such as asthma, should avoid prolonged outdoor exertion; everyone else, especially children, should limit prolonged outdoor exertion 201-300 Very Unhealthy Health warnings of emergency conditions. The entire population is more likely to be affected. globals_schema.formatted_aqi_T004:
Bangalore AQI Report - 2025-12-22

This report provides an overview of the Air Quality Index (AQI) in Bangalore on December 22, 2025.

Data Summary

Unfortunately, we do not have AQI data available for Bangalore on the specified date.

Possible Reasons for Missing Data

  • Data collection errors.
  • Sensor malfunction.
  • Temporary unavailability of reporting stations.

Recommendations

Please check again later, or try a different date. Consider consulting alternative data sources for historical AQI information.

Disclaimer

This report is for informational purposes only and should not be considered a substitute for professional environmental advice.

nodes.agent_prompt: Write a Python program to determine yesterday's date in 'YYYY-MM-DD' format and output it as `yesterday_date`. No explanation is required, just the code.

code_variants.CODE_1A:
import datetime

today = datetime.date.today()
yesterday = today - datetime.timedelta(days=1)
yesterday_date = yesterday.strftime('%Y-%m-%d')

return {'yesterday_date': yesterday_date}

import datetime

today = datetime.date.today()
yesterday = today - datetime.timedelta(days=1)
yesterday_date = yesterday.strftime('%Y-%m-%d')

return {'yesterday_date': yesterday_date}

nodes.description: Retrieve AQI data for Bangalore on specified date
nodes.agent_prompt: Scrape or use an API to retrieve the Air Quality Index (AQI) data for Bangalore on `yesterday_date_T001`. If possible, specify the data source in the output `raw_aqi_data_T002`

code_variants.CODE_1A:
results = json.loads(search_web_with_text_content('Air Quality Index Bangalore 2025-12-22', 5))
return {'raw_aqi_data_T002': results}

Air quality was satisfactory on 253 days, moderate on 81 days and unhealthy on 24 days. Relief came briefly during the monsoon months, with July at 60, August at 57 and September at 63. However, pollution levels climbed again post-monsoon, with October at 83, November at 124 and December averaging 143 so far. Out of 361 days in 2025 till December 27, Bengaluru enjoyed good air quality in only two days. Air quality was satisfactory on 253 days, moderate on 81 days and unhealthy on 24 days. Monitoring data confirms that no other year in the last five years has recorded such consistently high pollution levels. For comparison, the citys average AQI stood at 86 in 2020, 84 in 2021, 87 in 2022, 78 in 2023 and 73 in 2024, before jumping sharply in 2025. Bengaluru air turns dirtier month by month, 2025 worst in five years WELCOME, My Times LOGOUT SIGN IN Tue ,Dec 30, 2025 Mumbai Mirror | Pune Mirror Home Bangalore Cover Story Crime Civic Other Elections Entertainment Bollywood Hollywood Reviews Lounge South Masala Videos sectionhomelist News Sports Entertainment Photos Entertainment News Sports Sports Cricket Football Tennis Others News State India World Business Opinion Ask the Sexpert Sunday Read You Code 560 Others Views Food Teen Spirit Blogs Loksabha Elections Photos Videos Schedule Campaign Tracker Modi Meter Coronavirus All Coronavirus Cover Story Crime Civic Other Elections News Photos Videos Bangalore Cover story Crime Civic Others Entertainment Bollywood Hollywood Reviews Lounge South Masala Videos News Sports Entertainment Photos Entertainment News Sports Sports Cricket Football Tennis Others News State India World Business Opinion Ask the Sexpert Sunday Read You Code 560 Others Views Food Teen Spirit Blogs Others Letters to the Editor Sci-Tech Leisure Trending Today Lit.Mus 2014 Home / Bangalore / Civic / Bengaluru air turns dirtier month by month, 2025 worst in five years Bengaluru air turns dirtier month by month, 2025 worst in five years Updated: Dec 29, 2025, 06:00 IST Facebook Twitter Linkedin Email Share Facebook Twitter Linkedin Email Print this article Reduce font size Increase font size Bengalurus air quality has shown a steady month-on-month decline in 2025, overtaking pollution levels recorded five years ago and marking the citys worst performance in recent times. Data from monitoring centres shows that the average Air Quality Index has crossed 2020 levels, with overall air quality dropping by 22 per cent compared to last year. Grim comparison In February 2020, Bengalurus average AQI stood at 131. By December 27 this year, the average had climbed to 143, indicating a clear deterioration. On December 21, the city recorded an AQI of 175, placing it firmly in the unhealthy category. Experts point out that breathing Bengalurus air for a day is now equivalent to smoking nearly three cigarettes, underlining the health risk posed by prolonged exposure. Compared to previous years, 2025 has emerged as the most polluted year in the last five-year period. Seasonal spike Pollution levels began rising sharply after October this year. From December 5 onwards, the daily average AQI has consistently remained above 149. The city recorded a one-day average AQI of 166 on December 15, the second-highest daily average of the year. A similar spike was seen on November 28, when the AQI touched 167. Between October 1 and December 15, November 22 was the only day when the AQI dipped to a relatively low 52, falling under the good category, according to the data. Monthly pattern Month-wise data for 2025 shows worrying fluctuations. Out of 361 days in 2025 till December 27, Bengaluru enjoyed good air quality in only two days. Air quality was satisfactory on 253 days, moderate on 81 days and unhealthy on 24 days. Relief came briefly during the monsoon months, with July at 60, August at 57 and September at 63. However, pollution levels climbed again post-monsoon, with October at 83, November at 124 and December averaging 143 so far. Out of 361 days in 2025 till December 27, Bengaluru enjoyed good air quality in only two days. Air quality was satisfactory on 253 days, moderate on 81 days and unhealthy on 24 days. Monitoring data confirms that no other year in the last five years has recorded such consistently high pollution levels. For comparison, the citys average AQI stood at 86 in 2020, 84 in 2021, 87 in 2022, 78 in 2023 and 73 in 2024, before jumping sharply in 2025. nodes.description: Extract the AQI value from the retrieved data
nodes.agent_prompt: Extract the AQI value from the `raw_aqi_data_T002`.  If the data contains multiple AQI values for different locations or times, select the most relevant overall AQI for Bangalore for the entire day.  If the data is unstructured text, attempt to parse the AQI value. Save the extracted value as `aqi_value_T003`.

nodes.description: Present the AQI value in a user-friendly format
nodes.agent_prompt: Format the AQI value `aqi_value_T003` into a human-readable sentence stating 'The AQI in Bangalore yesterday was [AQI value]'.

output.fallback_markdown: Formatted report on Bangalore Air Quality Index (AQI) on 2025-12-22.
output.formatted_aqi_report_T005:
Bangalore Air Quality Index (AQI) Report - 2025-12-22

Executive Summary

This report provides an analysis of the Air Quality Index (AQI) in Bangalore on December 22, 2025. The AQI value for that date was 147, indicating 'Unhealthy for Sensitive Groups'. This report details the contributing factors and potential health impacts.

1. Introduction

Air quality is a critical environmental factor affecting public health. The Air Quality Index (AQI) is used to measure and report air quality, with values indicating different levels of health concern. This report focuses on the AQI in Bangalore on December 22, 2025.

2. AQI Value and Category

On December 22, 2025, the AQI in Bangalore was 147. According to standard AQI classifications, this falls into the 'Unhealthy for Sensitive Groups' category.

3. Health Implications

An AQI of 147 indicates that sensitive groups, such as children, the elderly, and individuals with respiratory or cardiovascular conditions, may experience health effects. These effects can include respiratory irritation, coughing, or difficulty breathing. Prolonged or heavy exertion should be limited for these groups.

4. Contributing Factors

Based on available data, the primary pollutant contributing to the AQI of 147 is PM2.5 (Fine particulate matter). Sources of PM2.5 include vehicle emissions, industrial activities, construction, and burning of waste.

5. Analysis of Recent Air Quality Trends in Bangalore (2025)

Data from 2025 indicates a concerning trend of deteriorating air quality in Bangalore. Compared to previous years (2020-2024), 2025 has recorded significantly higher pollution levels.

5.1 Month-by-Month Data

  • Only 2 days in 2025 had 'Good' air quality.
  • 253 days were classified as 'Satisfactory'.
  • 81 days were 'Moderate'.
  • 24 days were 'Unhealthy'.

5.2 AQI Levels by Month (2025 Average)

  • July: 60
  • August: 57
  • September: 63
  • October: 83
  • November: 124
  • December (up to Dec 27): 143

6. Comparison with Previous Years

The average AQI in Bangalore for previous years was significantly lower:

  • 2020: 86
  • 2021: 84
  • 2022: 87
  • 2023: 78
  • 2024: 73

This highlights a marked increase in pollution levels in 2025.

7. Recommendations for Mitigation

  • Reduce vehicle emissions by promoting public transportation, cycling, and electric vehicles.
  • Enforce stricter regulations on industrial emissions.
  • Control construction dust through proper site management practices.
  • Implement effective waste management strategies to prevent burning of waste.
  • Increase public awareness about air quality and its health impacts.

8. Real-Time Air Quality Monitoring

As of December 30, 2025, the AQI in Bengaluru is 147, categorized as Unhealthy for Sensitive Groups. The main pollutant is PM2.5 at 54.1 g/m.

9. Hourly Forecast

The AQI is forecasted to fluctuate throughout the day on December 30, 2025.

10. Precautions and Recommendations for Residents

  • Reduce outdoor exercise.
  • Close windows to avoid dirty outdoor air.
  • Sensitive groups should wear a mask outdoors.
  • Run an air purifier.

11. Data Sources

This report incorporates data from multiple sources, including:

  • Bangalore Mirror
  • IQAir
  • World Air Quality Index
  • Air Matters

12. Disclaimer

This report is for informational purposes only and should not be considered a substitute for professional environmental advice. Air quality data is subject to change, and real-time monitoring should be consulted for the most up-to-date information.

Bangalore AQI Report - 2025-12-22

This report provides an overview of the Air Quality Index (AQI) in Bangalore on December 22, 2025.

Data Summary

Unfortunately, we do not have AQI data available for Bangalore on the specified date.

Possible Reasons for Missing Data

  • Data collection errors.
  • Sensor malfunction.
  • Temporary unavailability of reporting stations.

Recommendations

Please check again later, or try a different date. Consider consulting alternative data sources for historical AQI information.

Disclaimer

This report is for informational purposes only and should not be considered a substitute for professional environmental advice.
